title: Astros back in World Series thanks to rookie pitcher José Urquidy's big start
text:
CLOSE What I’m Hearing: USA TODAY Sports' Bob Nightengale describes the mood in the Astros locker room after defeating the Nationals in Game 4, tying the series at 2-2. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – It’s not often a rookie pitcher with almost no postseason experience steps into the October spotlight and has the game of his life. But that’s exactly what Houston Astros right-hander José Urquidy did.

Trailing two games to one, the Astros pinned their World Series hopes on the right arm of a 24-year-old from Mexico on Saturday night. And he responded like a seasoned veteran.

“The man took the ball tonight and put on a great performance. I feel like it was the best performance from an Astro this year in the World Series,” Correa said. “He exceeded every expectation, he gave us a huge chance to win the game. He was perfect.”

Only the third native of Mexico to ever start a World Series game, Urquidy admitted he was a little nervous when he got the official word he’d be starting Game 4.

Astros rookie pitcher Jose Urquidy tossed five scoreless innings. (Photo: Geoff Burke, USA TODAY Sports)

“But after the first inning,” he said, “I felt very more relaxed.”

He retired the first two Washington Nationals hitters on harmless foul balls. After a single by Anthony Rendon, Juan Soto lined the next pitch into the glove of third baseman Alex Bregman for the third out.

That scoreless first inning was followed by another and another as Urquidy allowed only two hits in five shutout frames.

José Urquidy is just the fourth rookie in the last 30 years to throw a scoreless start in the World Series. pic.twitter.com/FZO2eWqLeo — ESPN Stats & Info (@ESPNStatsInfo) October 27, 2019

“He’s just fearless. His stuff was electric tonight and he was so much fun to watch,” said Astros reliever Brad Peacock. “He was just attacking everybody with all his pitches, throwing strikes with all his pitches. That’s the best I’ve seen him this year.”

When the Astros offense exploded and the rest of the bullpen finished off an 8-1 victory, Urquidy joined the great Fernando Valenzuela to become only the second Mexican pitcher to earn a World Series win.

“That means a lot to me,” he said. “I think this is now history, right? I feel very special for that.”

What was also special is that he was able to share the moment with his mother, Alma. The two talk a lot during the season and she was able to make the trip to Washington to see her son on the game’s biggest stage.

The two had coffee earlier in the day, and she was able to share some final words of encouragement. But even with all the attention from his home country, his family and Astros fans back in Houston, Urquidy reacted on the mound just the way he is in the clubhouse.

In Peacock’s words: “Chill.”

That was exactly what the Astros needed as they tried to stay calm and focused on their goal of evening the series.

“He’s a quiet kid. He doesn’t talk a lot,” said catcher Robinson Chirinos. “It’s not easy to go out there when your team’s 2-1 down and give a chance to win a game. But I think his personality –the way he is – allows him to perform on this kind of stage.”

Dropping in a variety of sliders and changeups, then mixing them with a fastball that topped out at 96 mph, Urquidy flustered the Nationals hitters by pitching backwards.

“He went against his percentages, which was smart,” Nationals right fielder Adam Eaton said as Urquidy ditched the changeup he usually throws to lefties in favor of his slider.

“When you go in with a game plan working off the scouting report and he goes the complete opposite with it, by the time you make the adjustments it’s too late.”

SPECIAL DELIVERY: Bregman delivers grand slam in Game 4 win

DECISIONS: Nats manager on bullpen: 'You don't chase wins'

It’s been quite a year for Urquidy, who missed the entire 2017 season recovering from elbow surgery and, until this spring, had never pitched above Class A.

A good, but not elite prospect, Urquidy was the opening day starter at Class AA Corpus Chiristi. He rose through the minors not only on the strength of his ability to make hitters swing and miss, but also on his excellent control.

He made his debut in early July when the Astros needed a spot starter due to injuries. The five starts he did make weren’t terribly impressive, but he did show enough promise with 24 strikeouts and only four walks in 23 innings.

After going back to the minors, Urquidy rejoined the team as a September call-up – with markedly better results. In 18 innings over four appearances down the stretch, he pitched to a 1.50 ERA with 16 strikeouts and three walks. That was good enough to earn a spot on the Astros’ postseason roster.

“He's evolved to being a very, very confident, very calm, very poised pitcher. And I noticed that during the Division Series in Tampa,” Astros manager A.J. Hinch said. “We asked him to do something he had rarely done; come out of the bullpen, middle of an inning, kind of the high stakes of postseason baseball, and he was up for the challenge.”

Despite pitching just 4 ⅓ innings in the Astros’ first two playoff series, he got the call from Hinch to start Game 4 because his manager liked his “demeanor” and his “approach.”

That decision was validated Saturday night when he outpitched the Nationals’ starter, $140 million free-agent signee Patrick Corbin.

“Everything for him was working tonight. His fastball. Changeup was unbelievable,” catcher Robinson Chirinos said. “His slider got so much better the last four weeks. That was the pitch he was struggling to when he was with us in July ... What a day for him.”

Thanks in part to Urquidy’s efforts, the Astros may have taken back control of the World Series. Even though the teams are tied 2-2, the Astros have aces Gerrit Cole and Justin Verlander on the mound for Games 5 and 6.

But for now, the night belonged to a 24-year-old rookie from Mexico.

“If you didn’t know who he was,” Hinch said, “I think this stage will make sure everybody knows who he is now.”
description: It’s not often a rookie with almost no postseason experience steps into the spotlight and has the game of his life. But that's what José Urquidy did.
